xxl.core.cursors.sources
Class Repeater<E>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<E>
      xxl.core.cursors.sources.Repeater<E>
Type Parameters:
E - the type of the elements returned by this iteration.
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.util.Iterator<E>, Cursor<E>
Direct Known Subclasses:
SingleObjectCursor
public class Repeater<E>
extends AbstractCursor<E>

A repeater reiterates a given object n times. The argument times may be specified by the caller, so the given object will be delivered by calls to the next method times times. Otherwise the same object will infinitely be returned to the caller, when invoking the next method. In that case the hasNext method never returns false.

Example usage (1): 

     Repeater repeater = new Repeater(new Integer(1));
 
     repeater.open();
 
     for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++)
         System.out.print(repeater.next() + "; ");
     System.out.flush();
     System.out.println();
 
     repeater.close();
This instance of a repeater returns an integer instance with value '1' infinitely often. With the intention to abort this operator, a for-loop is used returning only the first ten elements. In consequence the integer value is printed to the output stream for ten times.

Example usage (2): 

     repeater = new Repeater(new Integer(1), 10);
 
     repeater.open();
 
     while (repeater.hasNext())
         System.out.print(repeater.next() + "; ");
     System.out.flush();
     System.out.println();
 
     repeater.close();
This example shows a repeater with a given integer instance with value '1', which is returned for ten times, because in this case the user specified the parameter times in the constructor. The output is equal to that of example(1).

See Also:
Iterator, Cursor, AbstractCursor

Constructor Detail

Repeater

public Repeater(E object,
                int times)
Creates a new repeater. This repeater reiterates the input element only for a finite number of times.

Parameters:
object - the element that should repeatedly be returned to the caller.
times - the number of times the element should be repeated.

Repeater

public Repeater(E object)
Creates a new repeater. This repeater reiterates the input element infinitely often.

Parameters:
object - the element that should repeatedly be returned to the caller.
Method Detail

hasNextObject

protected boolean hasNextObject()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

Specified by:
hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
true if the repeater has more elements.

nextObject

protected E nextObject()
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the repeater's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.

Specified by:
nextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.

update

public void update(E object)
            throws java.lang.IllegalStateException,
                   java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
Replaces the last element returned by the repeater in the underlying data structure (optional operation). This method can be called only once per call to next or peek and updates the element returned by this method. Note, that between a call to next and update the invocation of peek or hasNext is forbidden. The behaviour of a cursor is unspecified if the underlying data structure is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

Specified by:
update in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
update in class AbstractCursor<E>
Parameters:
object - the object that replaces the last element returned by the repeater.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the update method has already been called after the last call to the next or peek method.
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the update operation is not supported by the repeater.

supportsUpdate

public boolean supportsUpdate()
Returns true if the update operation is supported by the repeater. Otherwise it returns false.

Specified by:
supportsUpdate in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
supportsUpdate in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
true if the update operation is supported by the repeater, otherwise false.

reset

public void reset()
           throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
Resets the repeater to its initial state such that the caller is able to traverse the underlying data structure again without constructing a new repeater (optional operation). The modifications, removes and updates concerning the underlying data structure, are still persistent.

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
reset in class AbstractCursor<E>
Throws:
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset operation is not supported by the repeater.

supportsReset

public boolean supportsReset()
Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the repeater. Otherwise it returns false.

Specified by:
supportsReset in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
supportsReset in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
true if the reset operation is supported by the repeater, otherwise false.
